title: Monday, 11th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

PM11:02am

PM11:05am

PM11:06am

Or in the market for cat bonds

11:05 am
BE11:06am

We're doing a "worst case avoided, rally" thing.

PM11:06am

Is that what it is

BE11:06am

At least at the Lloyds end of the market.

11:06 am
Lancashire Holdings Ltd (LRE:LSE): Last: 658.00, up 47 (+7.69%), High: 660.50, Low: 628.00, Volume: 703.12k
Beazley PLC (BEZ:LSE): Last: 477.90, up 26.9 (+5.96%), High: 480.90, Low: 460.00, Volume: 1.57m
BE11:06am

This is post Irma taking a late swerve west

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Which has pulled back the insured losses estimate to between $20bn and $65bn

PM11:07am

That's quite a spread, nevertheless

BE11:08am

Yeah, it's all probabilities. RMS puts that chances of losses above $60bn at 10%, which isn't all that comforting for people who remember other recent 10% probabilities.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Here's the gist via the trade press: http://www.insuran...r-florida-landfall

BE11:08am

And Peel Hunt with the maths.

BE11:09am

Hurricane Irma is now moving up the Florida Westcoast across the Tampa Bay areas as a category 2 Hurricane after making landfall just south of Naples with the intensity of a category 3/4. Irma moved gradually Westwards over the weekend and was initially tracking the path of Hurricane Donna, which in 1960 ravaged the Southwest Coast of Florida with 105mph winds.
At the time, Hurricane Donna made landfall as a category 4 hurricane and ran along the Southwestern Florida coast before turning inland at Bonita Springs.
Donna subsequently ripped through central Florida, passing by Orlando as a category 1/2 hurricane before exiting in the Atlantic. Hurricane Donna caused $46m of insured losses in 2015 dollars, according to catastrophe modelling agency Air Worldwide, and ranked 7th on the list of insured losses from major US Hurricanes since 1900.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Hurricane Irma is somewhat different. After making landfall as a category 4 hurricane with 130mph winds south of Naples, it has weakened and is tracking the Florida West Coast northwards as a category 2 Hurricane, with 100mph winds.
The projected path has Irma passing through the Pinellas region, which includes Tampa Bay. The Lloyd’s RDS scenario for a Pinellas major hurricane is for $134bn of insured losses across residential property ($95bn), commercial property ($40bn), Auto ($2bn) and Marine ($1bn). This scenario is as large as a Miami-Dade RDS scenario, hence the risk of major losses to the (re)insurance industry has not changed albeit given Irma’s weakened intensity, it will not be the same kind of loss event. Nevertheless, the region is likely to see major damage given the size of the storm, which stretches out to Miami.
It is obviously too early for catastrophe modelling agencies to estimate Irma’s losses even as we await definitive insured loss estimates from Hurricane Harvey.
These two hurricanes combined will be a major event for the industry and will erode catastrophe budgets across the reinsurance industry. The sector is now becoming more sensitive to further losses, which will start to significantly reduce returns below the cost of equity.

BE11:10am

And Cazenove, with a bit more maths

BE11:10am

We think Hurricane Irma could be a top 5 most costly hurricane in the U.S, although the losses could be in-line-to-lower than market expectations. Catastrophe modeler AIR Worldwide expects industry insured losses of $20-$65bn ($15-$50bn in the U.S. and $5-$15bn in the Caribbean) based on the track as of Friday evening, and our sense is losses could be at the lower end of the range as the storm weakened faster than expected. Catastrophe modeler RMS estimates there is a 90% chance the industry insured wind losses are less than $60bn (although storm surge could increase insurance losses by up to 30% and demand surge could add 15%).

11:11 am
BE11:11am

As a result, combined industry insured losses from Hurricane Irma and Harvey in 3Q (which could total $35-$80bn) could result in a stabilization of property catastrophe reinsurance prices, but is unlikely to result in meaningfully higher prices in our view. Nonetheless, we think the sell-off in the stocks since Hurricane Harvey more than reflects potential losses and P&C insurance stocks are poised to resume solid performance as they benefit from rational insurance pricing, consistent earnings and book value growth, and reasonable valuations. Historically, P&C insurance stocks rose on average 1% one month after landfall of major hurricanes and 9% on average three months after landfall. [GRAPH I'M NOT INCLUDING] shows our estimate of potential combined losses from Hurricane Irma and Harvey and the sell-off in the stocks since Hurricane Harvey intensified, which appears overdone.

BE11:12am

I've tonnes of this stuff. UBS?

BE11:13am

The hurricane's late move west has reduced risk to reinsurers to some extent, but with c$20-65bn of projected losses, combined with rising insured loss expectations for Harvey (now c$20-30bn), near term risks remain for the sub-sector and we still see likely positive rate moves at 1/1/18 renewals (beyond which the durability of third party capital markets will be the key price driver). The updated path of Irma appears to pose more risk to Lloyds of London based on RDS disclosures. At $20bn of insured losses for Harvey and $45bn for Irma, we model 3-5% hits to book value for reinsurers and 5-22% at the London Market insurers (see interactive model). Stocks seem to be pricing a $60-70bn industry Irma loss, which now looks conservative. We see Hannover Re as best positioned (SCOR also looks oversold), with most near term risk at Lancashire.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Can't link to UBS's interactive model, sadly. Give them some money for access to that.

PM11:14am

I was trying to find a price for the various Swiss Re Cat Bond indices

PM11:14am

11:15 am

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Anyway, back to the figures. Consensus isn't changing much.

BE11:25am

Have some Citi.

BE11:25am

Since 3Q trading update, Primark has delivered a 4Q LFL of c.+2% and an even lower level of markdown and as a consequence ABF now expects adjusted operating profit will be well ahead of last year (previously "good growth"). We would expect the better outlook in Primark to drive at least +1% upgrade to current consensus forecasts.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

FY17E Consensus PBT expected to rise slightly — Given the
strong 4Q trading at Primark we would expect a c.+1% increase in FY17e consensus. For the record we forecast £1260m FY17e PBT (EPS 123.0p, +15.9% yoy). This assumes +6.6% 2H17e EBIT growth trend split as follows – Sugar +175%, Agriculture -3%, Grocery -6%, Ingredients +7.5%, and Retail flat.

BE11:25am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:26am

- As usual for ABF, this pre-close statement is mainly qualitative rather quantitative in nature. However, the statement reads well and we think any moves today to consensus forecasts are likely to be modest, with risk to the upside following better than expected markdown performance in FYQ4 at Primark.
- At the divisional level investors' key focus today is likely to be on Primark, where full-year sales have come in at +13% on a constant currency basis, which is the same rate of growth given at the update in June at the FYQ3 stage. LfL for the year has come in at 1% (in line with consensus expectations). The positive surprise here on Primark, however, is on margins, which are now expected to be down less in the full year than they were in the first half, as a result of lower markdowns. Whilst this should be taken well, it is worth noting that Primark is expecting to open less space in FY 2017/18 than in FY 2016/17 and that management is guiding for margins to be "similar to this year" (i.e. there will be no significant recovery following this year's big fall).

11:26 am
PM11:26am

(Lefevre - he's ok. Soulful is Cardiff's steady state.)

BE11:26am

- Although Primark will be the key focus today, it is worth noting that the group is announcing a small(ish) acquisition in its Grocery division: Acetum (an Italian basalmic vinegar producer, which generated €103m of sales last year). The acquisition price is not disclosed, but we suspect it will make only a small dent in the group's very strong balance sheet: the statement today makes clear that the group will finish the year with around £650m of net cash.

BE11:27am

- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but the statement makes clear that management expects "good growth" in adjusted operating profit and EPS for the year. This is precisely the same guidance that management provided in the FYQ3 statement in June and suggests that any changes in consensus forecasts today are likely to be fairy modest. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for the group to report Pre Tax Profits of £1,357m (up 27% on the prior year).
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last Friday's closing price, ABF is trading on 23.4x Cal 2018e earnings, 12.6x EBITDA with a 1.4% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.0x, 7.6x and 4.5% respectively. Our reverse-engineered sum of the parts suggests that Primark is implicitly being valued at around 28x Cal 2018 earnings or 16x EV/EBITDA. This compares with Inditex which currently trades on around 24.2x and 17.9x respectively).

11:27 am
BE11:27am

So ... as I say, not much new. Apart from vinegar.

PM11:01am

11:30 am
PM11:30am

https://www.ft.com...tent:headline:html

PM11:31am

The Global Witness report cited there is here https://www.global...t_download_sng.pdf

PM11:31am

But back to Petra

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Well, yes. Even post the rally the market looks to have written off the value of Williamson and some more, which I guess prices in a certain amount of time and scrutiny.

PM11:31am

Williamson partly owned by the Tanzanian government

BE11:32am

Exactly, which makes Tanzania's complaint a little mysterious.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Cutting to Cannacord.

BE11:32am

The Tanzania government has stopped a 71.6kct export parcel of Williamson rough (value about $15m, we think); it believes they were incorrectly valued. Given valuation is a government responsibility, we find it difficult to see why Petra should suffer. In the meantime Petra has put the mine on a temporary production halt while its personnel engage with the government on the issue. Petra's share price response this morning appears overdone; Williamson is a small part of our valuation.

BE11:33am

That's part of a wider thing cutting forecasts a bit for poor grades.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

The biggest contributor to Petra’s high debt (net debt $554m at end-June 2017) has been lower-than-forecast grades in the recent past, we believe. Lower-than-expected grades at Cullinan after acquisition from De Beers in 2008 (~$30m a year less cash than anticipated); a delay in government approval of the Finsch acquisition as well as capex creep were negative to cash flow. So was the fact that Petra had 400kct less to sell in FY17 due to a production miss (potential cash flow ~$40m). The William export halt aggravates this, we think.

BE11:34am

While Petra has disappointed on achieving forecast production we believe the business model remains sound, though it will take longer to deliver the cash returns to equity.The banks' relaxing of covenants last week is also positive. If there is a lesson, perhaps it is that Petra attempted too many complex projects at the same time and management was stretched. Perhaps, we think, part of the solution may involve, over time, simplifying the group to focus on the three main producers, Cullinan, Finsch and, hopefully, Williamson.

BE11:34am

And BMO.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Not a Significant Contributor to Petra: For F2018, we currently forecast Williamson will contribute 6%, 11%, and 4% of Petra's production, revenue and EBITDA, respectively. Furthermore, we currently value Williamson at £61M (or £0.12/share), 7% of the group valuation, or 4% of the producing asset valuation. As per the current mine plan, Williamson has a mine life until 2033.

undefined
BE11:36am

Right, anyway, what else do we have?

11:36 am
PM11:37am

PM11:37am

BE11:39am

PM11:40am

11:39 am
PM11:40am

BE11:40am

Notable that the statement -- which, as you say, is a mess -- highlights sterling weakness as well as "reluctance" by customers to buy for next season.

BE11:41am

Shore has digested into bullet points.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

UP Global Sourcing (UP) has issued a full year trading update for its financial year ended 31st July 2017. The key features of the FY2017 performance highlighted in the update are:

· Group revenue growth of c39% to £110.0m (Shore Capital had forecast £107.5m), driven by 65% growth with UK & European discounters to £63.8m, 95% growth with UK Supermarkets to £10.3m and a 64% increase in online sales to £4.6m.

· FY2017 EBITDA and CPTP is above market expectations, we raise our EBITDA forecast by 5.4% to £11.5m and our CPTP by c6% to £10.6m (from £10.0m).

· Net debt is anticipated to be lower than expected due to a one-off tax credit of £2.1m and a favourable impact on year-end working capital from customer mix.

A tough start to FY2018 as retailers take cautious stock positions

However, whilst FY2017 exceeded expectations FY2018 has commenced amidst very challenging market conditions, with retailer concerns on future consumer spending activity (particularly on non-food lines) manifested in weak retailer demand and caution in forward buying into Autumn/Winter 2017. UP has suffered weak early year sales and order taking, in an important trading period for the group and against very demanding comparatives.

A short-term hit from business transfer of key European customer sales

In addition, whilst expected to be a major positive for the medium to long term, the transfer of sales to a major European retailer to a landed supply arrangement (from Free on Board) is expected to shift £4.0 - £5.0m of expected sales from FY2018 to FY2019 due to the phasing of revenue recognition.

PM11:41am

11:43 am
BE11:44am

We talked a bit a while back about the lagged effect of sterling's devaluation, because it takes a while for retailers' hedges to roll off.

BE11:45am

It might be that we're now seeing the effects of that -- which leads to a bump for the very bottom-end of the market essential retailers like Primark and a hit for everyone else.

BE11:45am

Exhibit A:

11:45 am
BE11:45am

https://twitter.com/jayforeman/status/906905441518616584

undefined
PM11:45am

That's a great image

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Should note AstraZeneca, which is up post ESMO.

BE11:47am

And the big held-back-for-maximum-effect updates on Pacific and Flaura.

BE11:47am

And it's good news! More or less. Infinzi (I'm calling it that because I can't be bothered typing the full compound name) significantly improves progression-free survival for lung cancer ....

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Thumbs up

BE11:48am

And Tagrisso (also lung cancer) is far superior to existing standard therapies.

PM11:48am

Thumbs upThumbs up

11:48 am
BE11:49am

It's the kind of studies drug companies deliver with great fanfare at ESMO to impress their peers, even though the readthrough for investors can be a little less obvious.

BE11:50am

HSBC has an excellent teardown of the Pacific data.

BE11:51am

Which, to remind, had already hit its PFS end-point

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And OS is due some time next year.

BE11:51am

We noted previously that other anti-PD1 immunotherapies (similar to AZN’s Imfinzi which is an anti-PDL1 immunotherapy) are already approved for the treatment for stage III NSCLC that has progressed after chemoradiotherapy. That Imfinzi has shown a benefit in stage III NSCLC patients who have not progressed after chemoradiotherapy is a nuance. There is unlikely to be anything magically different about a patient’s unresectable lung cancer that has not progressed after chemoradiotherapy that makes it uniquely sensitive to Imfinzi. The location of the cancer and therefore the ability to intervene surgically and the lack of progression of the disease are the only differentiating features of the PACIFIC study relative to other lung cancer studies to date with other immunotherapies already approved in NSCLC. We don’t believe location of the tumour and lack of progression are enough of a differentiation to demonstrate a clear benefit for Imfinzi, relative to other immunotherapies, especially in second/third line disease.

BE11:52am

This nuanced but important difference but may be completely irrelevant in the real world and questions the relevance of the PACIFIC data. If a patient has been though two rounds of cisplatin chemotherapy (which is toxic) plus radiotherapy – the standard of care – and their disease has progressed, we can rationalise why a patient may get treated with a USD150,000 drug. However, it is more difficult to rationalise treating a patient with a USD150,000 drug when their disease has not progressed after two rounds of chemotherapy and radiotherapy and even then, why the patient might not get treated with any of the anti-PD1/anti-PDL1 immunotherapies approved to treat second/third line lung cancer that are also already available. We make no change to our forecasts, 4,100p target price or Reduce rating.

11:52 am
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,880, up 89.5 (+1.87%), High: 4,944, Low: 4,866, Volume: 1.72m
BE11:53am

I should note that HSBC's cautious take isn't consensus.

BE11:53am

Consensus is Citi.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

We reiterate our Buy and £60 NPV derived target price. AZN’s PACIFC (Imflinzi) and FLAURA (Tagrisso) ESMO data sets in lung cancer were in line with our well above consensus expectations. In particular, we reiterate our confidence in our $5.9bn 2022 forecasts (consensus $3.5bn) for Tagrisso as the new standard of care in EGFR mutant NSCLC (lung cancer).

BE11:54am

Reiterating our $6bn Tagrisso forecast. We continue to anticipate Tagrisso will be rapidly adopted as the gold standard in EGFR NSCLC in both US and Japan given (i) significant 19 month PFS vs. control arm’s 10 month (ii) lesser adverse events (iv) efficacy in patients with CNS disease (iv) strong early trend to survival benefit. Longer term, high penetration in China also looks promising given more frequent additions to the NDRL. We anticipate US reimbursement through compendium listing by year-end and US and EU approvals in 2018. The market under-estimates the global opportunity given (i) still low EGFR testing rates in the US (65%) (ii) under-estimates of EGFR prevalence in US and Asia. The EMSO discussant’s caution over 1st line Tagrisso use driving increased transformation to small cell cancer was biased and scientifically imbalanced, we believe, with no supporting data from either FLAURA or AURA.

BE11:54am

PACIFIC data impressive but penetration slower. The 48% relative risk reduction with Imflinzi and limited adverse events deserve to make it standard of care regardless of the outcome of the maturing survival data. We estimate that c.20% of the 36 000 Stage III patients will be eligible for treatment. We estimate peak sales of $2bn in the PACIFIC indication.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

(@ROTR, are you really heading down the route of drawing up a carry trade on the arb potential of Primark's dual-currency pricing?)

undefined

Quick storm/insurance update

11:56 am

PM11:57am

to $20-40bn

PM11:57am

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Which seems to be the go-to data provider here

PM11:57am

BOSTON, Sept. 11, 2017 — Catastrophe modeling firm AIR Worldwide estimates industry insured losses in the United States resulting from Hurricane Irma will range from USD 20 billion to USD 40 billion. Note that these estimates are based on the NHC’s Sunday, September 10, 5:00 p.m. EDT forecast advisory for Irma. AIR Worldwide is a Verisk Analytics (Nasdaq:VRSK) business.

PM11:58am

So that fits the earlier trend -- it's not as bad as feared

11:57 am
PM11:58am

To insurers

PM11:58am

PM11:58am

http://www.air-wor...for-Hurricane-Irma’s-Impacts-in-the-United-States/

11:58 am
PM11:58am

KBW expecting a related bounce

PM11:58am

This morning, AIR Worldwide updated its U.S.-based insured loss estimates to $20-$40 billion, based on Sunday's 5 pm National Hurricane Center forecast. Given lower-than-expected loss estimates and solid performance from European (re)insurers, we expect primary and Bermudian insurers to trade up meaningfully on Monday.

AIR's current insured loss estimate includes wind and storm surge damage to both residential and commercial properties. AIR's estimates also include Personal and Commercial automobile losses, additional living expenses for residential properties, and business interruption coverage for commercial properties, but exclude potential inland marine losses.

We expect primary insurers and Bermudian reinsurers to trade up meaningfully today, reflecting the lower-than-expected insured losses that shouldn't significantly impair Bermudian and reinsurer capital

undefined
11:59 am
PM11:59am

Just checking whether we've missed anything obvious

BE12:00pm

It's very Monday. Not much coming out of the Sundays for us to cover either.

BE12:01pm

Lots of stories about people moving towards leaving jobs they've done for the legally required limit of time.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Oh! Carillion. Speaking of management churn.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 42.30, down 1.57 (-3.58%), High: 43.10, Low: 40.57, Volume: 8.51m
BE12:01pm

Zafar Khan, the CFO, is off. Immediate effect.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Emma Mercer, previously CFO of UK construction (!), takes over.

BE12:02pm

Plus three other exits, including former CEO Richard Howson

BE12:03pm

And they've got some guy on a secondment from E&Y to be "transformation officer"

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

What a mess

BE12:03pm

It's ............... well, let's be honest, we all know what it is. It's a shakeout in advance of a cash call.

BE12:03pm

Here's UBS.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

While we think a credible re-capitalisation and turn-around requires a new management team, the changes raise some questions: Timing is somewhat odd with H117 results due to be reported 29th September. Furthermore, Richard Howson had stepped down as CEO in July and was later appointed COO, only to leave the company now. Finally, the change in the Services management could raise questions given the July write-down only related to Construction with the Services business portrayed as in good shape.

BE12:04pm

As we have commented before, the outcome for shareholders from a restructuring and recapitalisation exercise is highly uncertain. We believe that the value to equity holders now mainly depends on whether the support services business also has problems or not. Our downside case, which assumes support services margins decline to 5% (base case 6%) and lower construction margins (1.5% for ex-ME; base: 2.0% and M.East: 2%; base: 3%), would leave no value for equity holders vs the 200m market cap.

BE12:05pm

Carillion investment case is pretty simple really: do the liabilities exceed the assets? And the only answer right now is, "dunno."
